abstract.text: We summarize the results of several searches for evidence of new physics phenomena using protonproton collisions at √ s = 7 TeV delivered by the Large Hadron Collider at CERN and recorded by the CMS detector in 2011.

body_text.text: Introduction
The Standard Model (SM) has proven itself over many decades to be in very good agreement with experimental results.

Despite this success, we realize that the SM is an incomplete theory and we therefore anticipate that the data delivered by the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN will contain evidence for new phenomena outside the current framework.
In this Note we summarize several searches for exotic new physics processes not currently explained by the Standard Model 1 .
These searches were conducted using √ s = 7 TeV pp collision data delivered by the LHC and collected by the CMS detector [1] in 2011.
Searches for New Heavy Charged Gauge Bosons
Various extensions to the Standard Model predict that new heavy gauge bosons may be found with TeV-scale masses.
body_text.section: Searches for New Heavy Charged Gauge Bosons

body_text.text: One such example is the W , which may be considered a heavy analogue to the SM W boson and possess the same left-handed fermionic couplings.
body_text.section: Searches for New Heavy Charged Gauge Bosons

body_text.text: CMS searches for this boson using 1.1 fb −1 of collision data via its leptonic decay mode W → ν, reconstructing final states containing an electron or muon and a neutrino [2].
body_text.section: Searches for New Heavy Charged Gauge Bosons

body_text.text: By examining the transverse mass distribution of the lepton and neutrino, where the neutrino presence in the detector is inferred from the missing transverse energy in the event (E miss T ), we find the data are in good agreement with SM expectations.
body_text.section: Searches for New Heavy Charged Gauge Bosons

body_text.text: Assuming SM-like couplings, we exclude W bosons with mass below 2.27 TeV at the 95% confidence level (C.L.).
body_text.section: Searches for New Heavy Charged Gauge Bosons

body_text.text: Due to the large expected mass of the W , the decay W → WZ is also allowed, and if the leptonic decays of the W are suppressed the decay rate to the WZ final state could be relatively enhanced.
body_text.section: Searches for New Heavy Charged Gauge Bosons

body_text.text: We also consider that certain versions of Technicolor, a strongly interacting gauge theory which allows for the dynamical breakdown of electroweak symmetry, describe techni-particles (e.g. ρ TC ) that may decay to the WZ final state with narrow resonant peaks.
body_text.section: Searches for New Heavy Charged Gauge Bosons

body_text.text: Searching in the WZ final state with 1.1 fb −1 of data, where both the W and Z decay leptonically, we exclude SM-like W bosons with mass below 784 GeV [3].
body_text.section: Searches for New Heavy Charged Gauge Bosons

body_text.text: We also compare our results in the WZ final states to predictions from Technicolor models and present 95% C.L. exclusion for ρ TC and π TC in Figure 1.
body_text.section: Searches for New Heavy Charged Gauge Bosons

body_text.text: Finally, we consider the possibility that the heavy W boson originates from an extension to the SM that includes a right-handed SU(2) symmetry group and search for the decay W R → N R , where the heavy neutrino N R is the right-handed analog of the SM neutrino ν L .
body_text.section: Searches for New Heavy Charged Gauge Bosons

body_text.text: Assuming righthanded couplings for the new heavy gauge boson, using 0.2 fb −1 we exclude in the two-
body_text.section: Searches for New Heavy Charged Gauge Bosons

body_text.text: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks
Precision electroweak measurements imply that the Standard Model can only accommodate three fermion generations.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: However, recently there has been renewed interest in extending the SM to include a fourth generation of fermions.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: Assuming a fourth generation, the indirect bounds on the mass of the Higgs boson could be relaxed, and a heavy fourth generation neutrino could be considered as a dark matter candidate.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: An additional generation of quarks may also possess enough intrinsic matter and anti-matter asymmetry to contribute to the baryon asymmetry of the Universe.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: Given this motivation, CMS searches for fourth generation b and t quarks, produced singly or in pairs, considering multiple final states.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: We search for pair-production of b quarks via the decay chain b b → tW −t W + and consider final states with three leptons ( = e, µ) or same-sign dileptons [5].
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: We also search for t t → bW +b W − , and consider final states where one [6] or both [7] of the W bosons decays leptonically.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: Standard Model expectations, which are dominated by tt production, are in good agreement with the results obtained using 1.1 fb −1 of data.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: As a result, we exclude heavy top-like (bottom-like) quarks with masses below 450 GeV (495 GeV) at the 95% confidence level.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: We additionally consider mixing between the third and fourth generations and search for fourth generation quarks produced singly (t b or b t) or in pairs as a function of the four-generation CKM matrix parameter A, where
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks
Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: This inclusive search requires at least one of the W bosons in the decay chain to decay to a muon and neutrino, and events are categorized according to the number of b-tagged hadronic jets and reconstructed W → qq candidates.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: We find no evidence for fourth generation quarks in this search.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: Assuming degenerate t and b masses, we summarize the 95% C.L. exclusion limits on fourth generation quark masses as a function of A in Figure 2.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: A search for vector-like quarks (T ) with charge |q| = 2 3 is also performed by CMS [9] using 1.1 fb −1 of collision data.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: We search for pp → T T production, followed by T → tZ → bWZ.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: Motivated by this decay chain, we search for events with at least two jets and at least three leptons, requiring that two of the leptons be consistent with Z → decay.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: Based on these requirements, backgrounds are dominated by events with real Z bosons.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: We find no excess beyond SM expectations, and conclude that M T > 475 GeV at the 95% confidence level.
body_text.section: Searches for Fourth Generation and Excited Quarks

body_text.text: Search for Extra Dimensions
The great disparity between the Planck scale (M Pl ∼ 10 19 GeV) and the electroweak scale (M EW ∼ 10 3 GeV) is a great mystery of the Standard Model.
The model proposed by Arkani-Hamed, Dimopoulos, and Dvali (ADD) includes a framework for addressing this hierarchy problem.

Taking the fundamental scale to be of the same order as the electroweak scale (M D ∼ M EW ), the observed weakness of gravitational interactions (equivalently, the large Planck mass) would be a consequence of the universe having compactified extra dimensions.
In the ADD model, the SM gauge interactions are constrained to the familiar 3 (space) + 1 (time) dimensional subspace while gravity is allowed to propagate through the entire multidimensional space.
Taking these hypothesized extra dimensions into account, the Planck scale is related to the fundamental scale by M 2
Pl ∼ M n+2 D r n , where r and n are the size and number of extra dimensions, respectively.
If M D is at the TeV scale, it would be possible to produce gravitons at the LHC.
Gravitons (G) could be produced directly at the LHC via the processes gg → qG, qq → gG, qg → qG, and qq → gG.
As the graviton escapes detection, we must search for evidence for extra dimensions in final states that include large E miss T .
CMS performs two searches of this nature, as we search for final states involving a real graviton balanced by a photon [10] or hadronic jet ( j) [11].

In each case, events are rejected if additional jets or isolated tracks are found with significant transverse energy, and additional requirements suppress beam backgrounds, cosmic ray signatures, and instrumental noise that may mimic the desired final state.
We present the leading jet transverse momentum spectrum for the j + E miss T channel in Figure 3.

Both the γ + E miss T and j + E miss T searches find no evidence for direct graviton production using 1.1 fb −1 of data, and set limits on the fundamental mass scale M D that depend on the number of extra dimensions considered.
Virtual graviton exchange is also possible at the LHC, which could lead to enhanced non-resonant dimuon production, which we consider in [12].
Using 1.1 fb −1 of data, we find results are consistent with SM expectations.
We consequently set 95% C.L. lower limits on the fundamental mass scale depend on the number of extra dimensions and additional theoretical conventions used to describe virtual graviton production.
Search for Microscopic Black Holes

One of the exciting potential consequences of theoretical models with extra spatial dimensions and lowscale quantum gravity is the copious production of microscopic black holes in particle collisions at the LHC.

We analyze events with large total transverse energy, searching for multiple high energy jets, leptons, and photons which are expected from the decay of black holes produced at LHC energies dominated by QCD multijet production, are in good agreement with the results found in data.
We therefore set limits on the minimum black hole mass that depend on the number of ADD extra dimensions and the fundamental mass scale M D .
Search for R-Parity Violation in Multilepton Events
One common feature of many Supersymmetric (SUSY) extensions to the Standard Model is conservation of "Rparity".
body_text.section: Search for R-Parity Violation in Multilepton Events

body_text.text: Conserving this quantity forces Supersymmetric particles to be produced in pairs and ensures the lightest SUSY particle (LSP) is stable and thus a good dark matter candidate.
body_text.section: Search for R-Parity Violation in Multilepton Events

body_text.text: As the LSP escapes detection, many SUSY searches require E miss T in the final state to account for the loss of the LSP.
body_text.section: Search for R-Parity Violation in Multilepton Events

body_text.text: If we instead consider models with R-parity violating interactions, the LSP loses stability and consequently decays to SM particles that could be observed in the detector.
body_text.section: Search for R-Parity Violation in Multilepton Events

body_text.text: As E miss T loses significance as a search quantity, we instead search for deviations from Standard Model expectations in events with significant total transverse energy [14].
body_text.section: Search for R-Parity Violation in Multilepton Events

body_text.text: Using 2.1 fb −1 of data collected in 2011, we consider 52 exclusive channels, categorized according to the number of leptons ( = e, µ) and same-flavor + − pairs in the event, the number of reconstructed τ leptons in the event, whether or not a Z → decay is reconstructed, and the total transverse energy in the event.
body_text.section: Search for R-Parity Violation in Multilepton Events

body_text.text: Several channels are dominated by SM processes and serve as control channels, while other channels expect negligible SM background contributions.
body_text.section: Search for R-Parity Violation in Multilepton Events

body_text.text: Datadriven methods are used to estimate background levels, including an estimate of asymmetric photon conversions using Z → µµγ → 4µ events.
body_text.section: Search for R-Parity Violation in Multilepton Events

body_text.text: We see good overall agreement with background expectations across all channels, and set limits on coupling strengths for R-parity violating SUSY interactions.
body_text.section: Search for R-Parity Violation in Multilepton Events

body_text.text: One such limit is shown in Figure 4.
body_text.section: Search for R-Parity Violation in Multilepton Events

body_text.text: In two channels with high total transverse energy, four leptons, and at least one same-flavor + − pair, we expect low backgrounds from SM processes but find a total of two events, finding one event each in channel (with or without a Z candidate).
body_text.section: Search for R-Parity Violation in Multilepton Events

body_text.text: While interesting, additional luminosity is required before we can access the significance of the result.
body_text.section: Search for R-Parity Violation in Multilepton Events

body_text.text: Search for Heavy Long-Lived Particles
Charged Particles
Heavy quasi-stable charged particles appear in various extensions to the Standard Model.
Heavy long-lived particles with a hadronic character, such as gluinos or stop squarks, will hadronize in flight and form meta-stable bound states with quarks and gluons.
If the lifetime of these so-called "R-hadrons" produced at the LHC exceeds a few nanoseconds, the particles will travel over distances that are comparable or larger than the size of the CMS detector.
Depending on particle lifetime and interaction with the detector material, CMS applies two complimentary techniques when searching for heavy long-lived charged particles.
The first approach assumes that a significant fraction of the R-hadrons will have a velocity smaller than 0.9c.

As a result, these particles will be directly observable through the distinctive signature of a high momentum particle with an anomalously large rate of ionization energy loss in the CMS tracker and an anomalously long time-of-flight as measured by the CMS Muon system [15].

We search for Rhadrons traversing the entire detector using both the tracker and muon systems, and additionally search using only the tracker information to account for the possibility that the particle may become neutral before reaching the muon detectors.

Using 1.1 fb −1 of data collected in 2011, searches for anomalous charged tracks allow us to exclude the production of gluinos, hadronizing into stable R-gluonballs with 10% (50%) probability, with masses below 899 (839) GeV at 95% confidence level.
The analogous limit on stop production is 620 GeV.
We also perform a search for low velocity (v < 0.4c) Rhadrons, where the energy loss is great enough that a significant fraction of the produced particles come to rest in
the CMS detector volume [16].
These "stopped" R-hadrons will then decay to hadronic jets at some later time depending on the unknown particle lifetime.
The decay of these particles will occur out-of-time with respect to LHC pp collisions, so our online (trigger) selection for stopped particles places a veto on the beam presence.

In a dataset with a peak instantaneous luminosity of 1.3 × 10 33 cm −2 s −1 , an integrated luminosity of up to 886 pb −1 lifetime, and a search interval corresponding to 168 hours of trigger live time, no significant excess above background (mostly from instrumental noise) was observed.
Limits at the 95% confidence level on R-hadron pair production extend over 13 orders of magnitude of gluino lifetime.
Neutral Particles
CMS also searches for long-lived neutral particles that are present in several exotic physics models.
In one such search, we consider pair production of long-lived neutral particles (e.g. H → χχ), each of which subsequently decays to a dielectron or dimuon pair [17].
As the massive neutral particles travel some distance in the detector before decaying, the χ → + − decay vertex will be displaced with respect to the pp collision vertex.
Using 1.1 fb −1 of collision data, we select e + e − and µ + µ − combinations that have large transverse decay lengths relative to the decay length uncertainty.
A single event survives the e + e − selection, consistent with expectations from Z → ee decay.
No events survive the muon selection.
In Figure 5 we present the 95% C.L. exclusion limits as a function of the decay length of the heavy neutral particle.
In some cases, the long-lived neutral particle may decay exclusively to other neutral particles (one example is the decay of a neutralino to a photon and a gravatino).
In these cases, we can exploit the large amount of tracker material in CMS to estimate the particle lifetime [18].
We search for photons that convert in the detector to a dielectron pair.

As the four-momentum of the γ → e + e − pair points along the same direction as the parent photon, the tracks of the electrons can be precisely reconstructed and used to calculate the photon trajectory and, in particular, the impact parameter of the photon with respect to the interaction point.

Examining 2.1 fb −1 of collision data for a photon with significant impact parameter in association with missing transverse energy (due to the escaping gravatino), we find the data is in good agreement with expectations from SM processes and determine the upper limits for the cross section for pair-production of neutralinos, each of which decays into one photon and invisible particles, as a function of neutralino lifetime.
Conclusion
In this Note we summarize several searches for exotic new physics processes not currently explained by the Standard Model.
In each search, the data are in good agreement with expectations from Standard Model processes.
We proceed to set 95% C.L. limits on the parameters and particle masses relevant for various new physics scenarios.
Fig. 1 .
Fig. 1.
Two-dimensional exclusion limit for Technicolor in the WZ final state as a function of the ρ TC and π TC masses.
Fig. 2 .
Fig. 2.
Expected and observed exclusion limits for M t = M b as a function of the four-generation CKM parameter A as described in the text.
The parameter values below the solid black line are excluded at 95% C.L.
Fig. 3 .
Fig. 3.
Transverse momentum distribution for the leading jet in the jet+E miss T search for extra dimensions.
The leading jet is required to have p T > 100 GeV and be reconstructed within the acceptance of the CMS tracker.
Fig. 4 .
Fig. 4.
95% C.L. limits for R-Parity violating coupling λ 122 = λ eµµ as a function of the squark and gluino masses for a SUSY topology described in[14].
The observed limits, along with limits expected in the absence of signal are shown, in addition to the uncertainty in the expectation.
Masses to the left of the curves are excluded.
Fig. 5 .
Fig. 5.
95% confidence level upper limits on the cross section and branching fraction for the assumed H → χχ decay, with χ → ee (left) and χ → µµ (right), assuming a Higgs mass of 1000 GeV.
The expected limit band for the electron channel is too small to be visible.
This note is not intended to summarize all searches for new physics phenomena conducted by CMS.
Discussions of CMS searches for the Higgs boson, Supersymmetry, and exotic resonances can be found in other proceedings for this conference.
